Kick is yet another ode to Salman's star power, a scintillating addition to the pantheon of "bhai" movies which are made solely because of the fact that his crazy fans will pay to see their hero on screen- wriggle, giggle, waddle, dawdle, strut, and shake- any number of times.

In Kick, Salman essentially plays his own larger than life character on screen- Devi Lal Singh, good at heart, physically tough and a balls out crazy genius. He is someone who can do anything and everything- a scientific genius as his multitude of degrees and doctorates prove, he can do daredevil stunts on fast bikes and jump across skyscrapers, and in the defense of a couple in love, when he hits one goon, others simply disappear. In short this man is more superhero material than the entire Avengers team combined, and everyone in the film, including his father (Mithun Chakraborty) and even the police cop chasing him (Randeep Hooda) is almost reverential in their love for Devi. He has one condition for his superhero-giri though- he should get a kick out of it, an adrenalin rush.

Does Kick then becomes the longest Mountain Dew ad in the world? Sadly, no. Because in the 146 minutes running time, Salman's kick inducing moments are too far and too few.

Who needs a director for a Salman movie, thought Sajid Nadiadwala, and he makes his directorial debut with this formulaic film. Adrenalin junkie Devi Lal's thirst for kicks and his own pride nips his budding romance with the always impeccably dressed psychiatrist Shaina (Jacqueline Fernandez). But then, women really do not matter in a Salman movie- for his fans, he might as well romance a banyan tree for all that matters, not someone as pretty as Jacqueline. Cheers and wolf whistles will be guaranteed even then. Devi Lal's innate sense of justice and humanity transforms him into the masked Devil- a Zorro like character who steals from the rich and gives to the poor. Ironic though, because after raking 50 crores in 2 days, and set for more in the next few weeks, the only people laughing off to the bank will be Salman and Sajid.

The first half of the movie is dull, the second half is where things brighten up. My advice, enter only after the interval. Bike chases, heists, catchy songs all are in the second half, along with a scene stealing Nawazuddin Sidiqque as the loony, craven nephew of a corrupt politician. Is he the poor man's Irfan? Might be so for the time being, but looking at Irfan's trajectory, this guy will also go places.

If Aamir is presumably trying to change the world through works such as Satyamev Jayate, Salman used his own perceived "heart of gold" personality to do his version of "do good" in Jai Ho, and follows it up in Kick. Jumma is in the air for bhai fans, for them the movie is drool- worthy stuff, all out Salman. Even the movie poster features only himself! Others- know that you have been warned- 5/10

The story's premise and central conflict are laid out in the second half, leading up to a dramatic and uplifting climax. In fact, I think this film will end up being Salman Khan's most successful to date. The actor-turned-director Sajid Nadiawala showed promise in his filmmaking debut. The media's skepticism of Salman Khan's newfound maturity, in my view, is unfounded. No matter what movie he directs, complications occur, but he always gets his way. Even if you don't think the choreography is great, you can't deny that Jackline Fer and Salman Khan have great chemistry together. Now everyone in Hollywood wants to be seen with them. They need to make more of an effort going forward. This means that kick is perfect in every way and meets all requirements.

review_title: Dil mein ati hai but samajh me nahi ati
review_detailed_main:
Kick the latest action movie starring Salman Khan is the remake of a telegu movie with the same name. One could guess right of the bat that this movie is no different than any of the recent movies featuring Salman Khan, a no brainer with a lot of low quality special effects action.

The movie has weak story line and a poor script with the main character (Salman Khan) looking for what he calls a "kick" in everything. One simply doesn't expect this kind of movie from Sajid Nadiawala. The movie features Randeep Hooda as a very smart and highly reputed cop ,but apparently he cannot even figure out who the culprit is even when his entire profile is described to him by Jacqueline Fernandez. The movie is riddled with several such logical loopholes. The only watchable parts of the movie are the songs "Hangover" and "Yaar na miley" ,the latter featuring Narghis Fakhri giving a very much needed guest appearance. The biggest plight is that in spite the movie fails all over the board it has become the highest grossing Bollywood movie of the year 2014 (kinda makes you wonder about the taste of people nowadays).

All in all its a pretty good movie to update yourself to the standard Indian movies have fallen to in present times. It is a must watch if you find yourself having a few extra hundred bucks and nothing to kill time, you might get a few pity laughs out of it.

I would not go into detail about the narrative since doing so might spoil your viewing experience. It is important not to compare this film to the Telugu original and to watch it with an open mind. The HR score is wonderful, but the action scenes are the focus of the show. In his debut as a director, Sajid Nadiawala performed well. Salman, the Bollywood star machine, is the pied piper. He does not guarantee the production of new or art house films. Three enchanting words are highlighted: entertainment, entertainment, and entertainment. This is the primary concern of the great majority of moviegoers. It would not be an exaggeration to say Salman is KICK's soul.

After a series of Bad movies (real bad) except the decent EK tha Tiger, this one is a kick for the Dabangg khan to uplift his falling career. Honestly, I had almost Zero expectations. The trailer was also not very exciting and my presumption about the moving having no story stood 100% correct. 4 writers credited(even including Chetan Bhagat), but what you get is inconsistent & and an incoherent screenplay.

There are snatches of Batman, Zorro, Dabangg, Aks, Bodyguard & Especially Dhoom:3. In fact many from it. But where Dhoom:3 failed miserably to deliver any kinda Fun, Kick does it right. It's moreover a Dhoom 3 done right. Salman is Outstanding. He plays himself. Like the dialog-"Main Dil main aata hun, samajh main nahin", it's a larger than life character best suited to him. The action(though very less) was brilliant. Considering its a Bollywood movie, the production values were superb. Especially a chase sequence in Poland looked spectacular. Songs are decent with good presentation. Among the rest, almost everyone performed hammy yet amazing.

Randeep Hooda did what Abhishek Bachchan should do in a better way, Jacqueline Fernandis too was impressive. It was Nuwazuddin Siddique in the second half who took the maximum claps with a superb performance. He was notches higher in scenes with Salman.

The cinematography deserves special mention. It was fab and a bit artful!

Overall, despite its flaws, lack of logics, zero story, and some exceeded runtime, Kick does succeeds in providing decent entertainment. A good Eid-flick. Extremely Watchable. And that extra 0.5 is for Salman and his dancing. LOL!

review_title: This film kicks all the bad movies and becomes the worst
review_detailed_main: If you wanted to see a superhero movie, like Spiderman, with amazing cinematography, great storyline, a movie which will captivate you for the whole runtime, a professional made film, then you picked seriously wrong! Same as Bodyguard, Dabangg 2, Kick is also a time waster, with no story. Salman looks pretty cool and has a charming style, but thats the only good thing i can say about this film. It has some average songs which are placed totally wrong during the movie, almost as wrong as some annoying TV commercials. I like hearing some nice songs during an Indian movie, but they shouldn't be placed so randomly.....and all that dancing and the costums, dancers, backgrounds and all it's pretty silly.......i mean, is it a movie or a stage show??? Ek Tha Tiger was 100% better made than this. Even Jai Ho had some nice parts. Well, i guess it can be a good entertaining piece for those masses from India, but it really isn't a good quality film. Far from it. That stunt where Devi jumped from the window is sooooo bad, my God, i can clearly see Salman's double, and the editing is simply terrible, which makes me believe that it's the work of an amateur. They even speculated something about working with a stunts director from Hollywood...it's really disappointing. When he's driving that bus, cars are getting crashed although is clear they aren't even touching the bus, is just hilarious. Tere Naam, Lucky, Wanted, Sajaan, Garv,...yeah, there weren't the best movies in the world, but they were enjoyable, good to watch, some i even watched again and again. But this one, with all the car crashes, explosions and all, is a very weak movie. Well, what do you expect from a man who became movie director over night? Just amateur work. Salman should stop making such movies which are pulling him down really hard. I give it 5 out of 10 stars, just for Salman's look and performance and because i'm one of his fans. But i'm disappointed.

review_title: Bollywood movie strongly need a good Scriptwriter
review_detailed_main: Today I saw Devil(2009) , oh sorry Kick(2014). There are few ways the writer explained how the name is given Kick. I'm a fan of Salman Khan, but it'll again disappoint you.

review_title: They educate one another about the past
review_detailed_main: To begin, KICK! Is an idea worth exploring. The attractive doctor Shaina-Jacqueline Fernandez meets her future husband, the Indian police officer Himanshu-Randeep Hooda, on a train in Warsaw. They educate one another about the past. In this excerpt from her memoir, Shaina tells the tale of her exes, including the sadistic Devi Lal Singh-Salman Khan, who was obsessed with the video game "Kick." She brags to her friends about him and their brief relationship until he suddenly abandons her for another high. Himanshu tells her of his heroic feats and how he finally met his match in the form of a crafty thief.

review_title: No kick to take from it
review_detailed_main:
I watched this with my brother who is a die hard fan of Salman, of course being a 90s and early 2000s movies, I wasn't too keen on the movie. I just wanted to spend some time with my bro and that's why decided to watch together. Safe to say my negative opinion of the movie did not change. Weaknesses are numerous:

Acting : Salman's character was extremely poorly written. I have not seen such senseless people in the real world. I expect reel characters to have some sort of similarities to real life people, but sorry to say adrenaline junkies are hardly like this. He gave one of his worst acting performances as well which did not help things at all. Really his box office success has coincided with his dwindling acting efforts. Jacqueline is stoic and expressionless and just like Katrina delivers dialogues with a foreign accent which is irritating in a Bollywood flick. The kids also did not get any tears out of my eyes whatsoever as I did not relate with their grief at all. Only saving graces were Nawazuddin Siddique and Randeep Hooda in terms of acting.

Wafer thin plot : There is no real story whatsoever. The story keeps jumping from flashbacks to present abruptly and incoherently which adds an element of illogicality to the movie. The movie has been advertised as a thriller in some places but there is no thrill whatsoever in the story. I even don't criticise predictable thriller but the movie isn't remotely close to a thriller. The journey of Salman seems very stretched and bores you seriously right from beginning to end.

Extremely poor action sequences : I am not at all a fan of action. I only like action when it is kept logical and without all those irritating sounds and one man beating up thousands. This film had many of the aspects of action which annoy me. I slept through the action scenes because after a stage, they were unwatchable.

Too preachy: The film is clearly a way to demonstrate the greatness of Salman as a human and reflects on his charity work quite clearly. I have read about all these stuff on Internet. While I appreciate his efforts but I feel it is an incredibly boring topic to make a movie on, the movie should've been listed as a documentary rather.

Forced comedy : The movie has been enlisted as one belonging to the comedy genre. It had nothing but crass, forceful and utterly unimpressive comedy. Every single situation which tried to extract a laughter led to irritation and not once throughout the movie was I remotely close to laughing.

Animated childhood: There was no precautions about inserting animations. Right from my childhood, I believe in watching realistic movies and have never been fascinated by all these superheroes,cartoons,animation and caricatures. The director should've made the effort to enlighten audiences of what to expect which might not be what the audience is prepared from the buildup and trailer. Animated movies are a completely different genre and they should, in no way be included in movies about real people and situations.

Kick A, Kick A background noise : After Salman's weird and stupid actions, there is a continuous disturbance in the form of that Kick A Kick A thing, really gets on your nerves, I can assure you Strengths: Music : None of the songs are too pleasing to the ear with the exception of Hai Yehi Zindagi. That song hits the jackpot and convinced me to declare this aspect of this movie as a strength. Real touchy one which was the only significant takeaway from the movie.

Location: The Polish locations were eye catching and enhanced the viewing experience.

review_title: It's all about SALMANISM and BEING HUMANISM but I didn't feel that KICK
review_detailed_main:
Kick : Clear definition of this word is "strike or propel forcibly with the foot" and its a verb but what does SALMAN meant to say about KICK? What is his KICK?. In the whole drama he always utters" isse mujhe kick nahin milti". Debuntante Director Sajid Nadiadwala comes into direction after producing blockbusters in his earlier works, a good way to start his career in direction with Bhaijaan where he knows making a full fledged movie with him can earn him a lot overnight,irrespective of lousy plot. review_title: Kick is a smelly sock placed in an fancy box and wrapped in a silver foil.
review_detailed_main: Last night, through the rustling wind and pounding rain, I heard the faint strains of a song. It was the Spirit of Bollywood crooning a melancholy melody, reflecting upon the newest product it had just belched out. Kick is almost there: it melts the brain, burns a hole in your pocket and causes a tsunami of rage within you. A poster of the film.xactly like every other previous Bhai film, made for Bhai fans. This means a) The script would depress a dull primate b) All women in the film are utterly stupid, c) Bhai is an angelic godlike creature sent to us by Lord Xenu only to be worshipped d) There have to references to previous Bhai films. It's called being meta. What's that you say? This Bhai film is different and good because it has a huge budget and is set in phoren locations? If Jai Ho was a smelly sock, then Kick is a smelly sock placed in an fancy box and wrapped in a silver foil. You open the box and the effect is still the same. The massive budget of the film doesn't much manifest itself into the visuals in a convincing manner. There is an appalling animated sequence and the CGI looks like it was made for a few rupees in a basement Pentium 2 PC. In a scene where Bhai drives a bus through parked cars, the cars fly around like video game rag dolls. But once again, this is a masala commercial film and I shouldn't expect anything smart or classy. Right? Wrong. You can choose to have a good script. You can choose to entertain audiences by not insulting their intelligence. You can choose to not have Jacqueline Fernandez playing a psychologist whose idea of treating a patient is to bring him home and then take him to a bar. You can choose to not show Saurabh Shukla bent over an exercise ball with a hulking, tattooed yoga instructor looming over him. The only agenda that Kick has is to squeeze Bhai into every frame of the film and make him a contrived superhero. I'll avoid making any Kick puns about how hard the blows feel, but I can tell you the film does contain one interesting scene. Bhai dances in a club to 'Saat samandar paar' and jeers at Randeep Hooda by showing him the text on the back of his T shirt – it reads 'LOSER'. Is that meant for the audience or Khan being self-deprecating? I don't think so. The supporting cast in Kick, despite looking decent on paper, doesn't work very hard either. Considering the script, it's not surprising since everyone in the Kick universe exists only to make Bhai's idiotic superhero look "cool". Hooda sneers his way through the film and Nawazuddin Siddiqui hams to the hilt — every time there's a manic bark of laughter from him, it's like he's imagining the sound of his bank account being credited. As is the case with most Bhai films, none of the setbacks are going to matter as such, because for die-hard Bhai fans, they're trifles in a box of goodies. And a review of the film is hilariously useless, because no known force on this planet can stop a Bhai film from sending the box office registers ringing. Bhai seems to have discovered the elixir of life with the Eid release strategy. In the annals of time whether or not the chaand shows up, a Bhai film certainly will. No wonder then that the Spirit of Bollywood wandered through the city last night, drunk and depressed. The last words of its song are a haunting echo: I tried so hard and got so far. In the end, it doesn't even matter.

review_detailed_main:
So Salman Khan once again comes up with his big budget release on Eid. Kick is a Bollywood remake of South Indian movie of the same name. It is directed by debutant Sajid Nadiadwala. It stars Salman Khan, the protagonist, as Devi Lal Singh aka Devil, Jacqueline Fernandez as Dr. Shaina, Randeep Hooda as Inspector Himanshu Tyagi and Nawazuddin Siddiqui, the antagonist, as Shiv. Music is given by Himesh Reshammiya.

STORY: Devi Lal Singh (Salman Khan) is a fun loving guy who falls in love with Dr. Shaina. Devi always wants to try something different and always wants a 'kick' in his life. Situations separate them both. Dr. Shaina goes to Poland and Devi Lal becomes Devil, the thief. After Devil, is Inspector Himanshu Tyagi played by Randeep Hooda. Then comes the antagonist, Nawazuddin. The story unfolds. Watch the movie to find out more.

SCREENPLAY: The screenplay is very poor. There's no pace in the movie. Some sequences are very dull especially in the first half. Second half picks up a bit. Just a bit.

ACTING: Salman Khan is good. Jacqueline is decent. Randeep is good as well. Nawazuddin looks a misfit. He does not look like a villain at all.

MUSIC: Music is above average. Jumme ki raat is worth a watch.

OVERALL: Kick is as good as Ek Tha Tiger, Bodyguard and Dabanng 2. It is a typical nonsense masala movie with no proper script. Watch only and only for Salman Khan.

Salman Khan, please come up with something better next time. Thanks!

Salman, the star machine, is the Pied Piper of Hindi cinema. He doesn't promise path-breaking or art house cinema. The focus is on those three magical words: Entertainment, entertainment and entertainment. And that's what matters to a wide majority of movie-going audience.

To state that Salman is the soul of KICK wouldn't be an exaggeration. He's committed, charming and competent, so much so that it's difficult to take your eyes off him. Post DABANGG, those who felt that the actor's movies lacked a cohesive script to match his superstardom, are sure to feel satiated with KICK, since the film has it all and does utmost justice to Salman's aura. In fact, the film gives him the platform to exhibit his range as an actor/star and his real-life role of a good Samaritan/humanitarian further. Rest assured, the fans and the fanatics -- even those who aren't -- are in for a treat!

Randeep Hooda is supremely efficient, delivering a performance that stays with you. And this is a huge compliment, since the film is a Salman show from commencement to conclusion. Nawazuddin Siddiqui is a powerhouse of talent and KICK gives him the opportunity to cross over to the commercial league. Nawazuddin is simply outstanding, essaying his part with gusto. In fact, it won't be erroneous to state that along with Salman, Nawazuddin will walk away with plaudits after KICK.

Jacqueline Fernandez does very well, although her diction needs to be worked upon. She looks great and her dance in 'Jumme Ki Raat' is sure to stun you. Mithun Chakraborty is in top form yet again. The sequence with Salman towards the concluding moments stay with you.

The supporting cast -- Saurabh Shukla-good, Sanjay Mishra-awesome, Vipin Sharma-super, Archana Puransingh-alright, Kavin Dave-first- rate, Sumona Chakravarti-perfect -- each of them contribute well to the proceedings.

On the whole, KICK is a paisa vasool, seeti-maar entertainer. Get ready for a Tsunami called KICK at the ticket window. It is sure to rewrite box-office records. Salman fans, rejoice. KICK is a sure-shot B-L-O-C-K- B-U-S-T-E-R. To quote a dialogue from the film: 'Woh apni Eidi lene zaroor aayega'.

Just like 'Salman', the storyline of his films convey the dialog 'dil mien aata Hun...samajh mien nhi'. However unlike his typical mas-ala potboilers, this one has a riveting storyline along with doses of entertainment. YES, KICK has the magnificence that was lacking in Salman's previous movies.

The first half is blended with several comic and romantic scenes where Salman is crazy, never like before. Special mention to that Police Station episode where 'Sanjay Mishra', 'Mithoon' and 'Salman' make you go LMAO! But your intuition of the film being a typical 'Salman; entertainer proves false with 30 min to the brilliant interval point. It's the second half that gives the film a 'KICK' to a new level which with Salman bringing a different shade to his character. The suspense emotional plot is appealing and climax will stun you with it's snazzy, breathtaking action sequences and the brilliant execution. The dialog's are a topnotch. Take a bow 'Rajat Arora'. Truly clap and whistle worthy. Music is one of the USP's of the film where 'Jumme Ki Raat' is already a rage, 'Hangover' and 'Yaar Na Miley' add up to the rhythm of the film. Blemishes? Yes, in the first half, one or two sequences seem to be dragged. However 'Sajid Nadiadwala' excels with a milestone in his first directorial venture. He presents 'Salman' in such a way that he's beyond 'MESMERIZING' in the entire film from the comic, action, romantic sequences to the emotional one's. He carries of the role with flamboyance proving out to be one of the best performances of his career. 'Jacqueline' gets biggest role of her career and makes her presence felt, especially in a key dramatic scene with 'Salman'. She looks smoking hot and her dance will make you go gaga. 'Randeep Hooda' is supremely efficient, delivering a performance that stays with you. 'Nawazuddin Siddiqui' is a powerhouse of talent and KICK gives him the opportunity to cross over to the commercial league. Nawazuddin is simply outstanding, essaying his part with gusto. In fact, it won't be erroneous to state that along with Salman, Nawazuddin will walk away with plaudits after KICK.

All in all, a full-on commercial film which is not just relies on Salman but is backed by a good plot and treatment that gives a joy ride. BLOCKBUSTER written all over it!

Directed by Sajid Nadiadwala and starring Salman Khan in the lead role, the film follows the story of a man named Devi Lal Singh, also known as Devil, who craves excitement and thrills in life. Devi's character is portrayed as a quirky and unpredictable individual who finds joy in performing audacious acts, often for the greater good.

One of the film's highlights is its action sequences, which are choreographed with precision and flair. From exhilarating chase scenes to jaw-dropping fight sequences, "Kick" delivers on the promise of edge-of-your-seat entertainment. Salman Khan shines in his role as Devil, bringing charisma and energy to the character. His chemistry with co-star Jacqueline Fernandez, who plays the female lead, adds a layer of romance to the narrative.

However, while "Kick" excels in its action and entertainment quotient, some viewers may find the plot to be predictable. The storyline follows a familiar trajectory, with the protagonist battling against a corrupt system and facing personal dilemmas along the way. Despite this, the film manages to maintain its momentum through its brisk pacing and engaging performances.

Another aspect of "Kick" worth mentioning is its music, which features catchy songs that complement the film's mood and tone. Tracks like "Jumme Ki Raat" and "Hangover" became instant hits among audiences, adding to the film's commercial success.

In conclusion, "Kick" is a Bollywood masala entertainer that delivers on its promise of action, romance, and drama. While its storyline may not break new ground, the film compensates with its slick production values and charismatic performances.
